lexicon_requests.reason: Specific geographic term - why 'islands' rather than nations/peoples in universal context
Theophanic darkness vocabulary - technical term for divine hiddenness
Architectural foundation term - precise vocabulary for throne establishment
Intensive burning verb - specific fire imagery in divine procession
Earth's convulsion reaction - possible labor pains imagery, unusual cosmic response
Wax in mountain-melting simile - why this specific material for permanence dissolving
Reflexive boasting about idols - precise vocabulary for idol worship hubris
Divine supremacy title - theological significance in hierarchical context
Loyal/devoted ones - covenant relationship terminology and semantic range
Light being 'sown' - agricultural metaphor puzzle, passive construction significance
Memorial/remembrance of holiness - liturgical memory vs present experience

concordance_requests.purpose: Track YHWH kingship formula across enthronement psalms
Geographic scope of 'many islands' in biblical literature
Divine beings references in monotheistic contexts

figurative_requests.reason: Throne foundation imagery - architectural metaphor for divine justice | Vehicle: foundation | Related terms: foundations, base, bases, establish, established, establishing
Fire as military vanguard - personified flame in divine procession | Vehicle: vanguard | Related terms: advance, advancing, precede, preceding, herald, heralds
Earth convulsing/trembling - vivid cosmic personification | Vehicle: convulse | Related terms: convulsing, tremble, trembles, trembling, shake, shakes, shaking, quake, quaking
Mountains melting like wax - striking simile of permanence dissolving | Vehicle: melt | Related terms: melting, melts, dissolve, dissolves, dissolving, flow, flows, flowing
Heavens as heralds - cosmic proclamation personification | Vehicle: proclaim | Related terms: proclaiming, proclaims, declare, declares, declaring, announce, announces, announcing
Light sown like seed - unusual agricultural metaphor for divine provision | Vehicle: sown | Related terms: sow, sows, sowing, plant, planted, planting, seed, seeds

commentary_requests.reason: YHWH kingship formula and islands specification - how commentators interpret universal vs. geographic scope
Theological paradox of divine hiddenness and moral foundation - traditional resolution of darkness/righteousness tension
Fire as divine vanguard - classical understanding of theophanic fire imagery and military metaphor
Cosmic response sequence - how commentators explain causation between lightning revelation and earth's convulsion
Mountain-wax melting simile - traditional interpretation of this vivid permanence-dissolution metaphor
Heavens proclaiming vs. peoples seeing - commentators on different modes of divine revelation
Divine beings identity and submission - classical exegesis of monotheism and heavenly hierarchy
Geographic shift to Zion/Judah - how commentators explain transition from universal to particular
Divine supremacy assertion - traditional understanding of YHWH's exaltation over other divine beings
Ethical imperative following cosmic display - commentators on connection between theology and ethics
Light sowing metaphor - classical interpretation of this puzzling agricultural imagery
Concluding imperative and holy remembrance - how commentators understand liturgical memory and inclusio structure

macro_questions: How do the theophanic elements (clouds, fire, lightning, melting mountains) compare to other biblical theophanies and Ancient Near Eastern storm god imagery, and what theological significance lies in their specific combination here?
What is the precise meaning and scope of 'many islands' (אִיִּים רַבִּים) in v. 1 - does this refer to distant gentile nations, and how does this relate to the psalm's universal claims?

How does the theological paradox in v. 2 function - 'clouds and darkness around Him' yet 'righteousness and justice are the base of His throne' - and what does this reveal about divine hiddenness and moral clarity?
What is the identity and significance of 'all divine beings' (כׇּל־אֱלֹהִים) who bow down in v. 7 - angels, foreign deities, or both - and how does this relate to divine council imagery?
How does the shift from third-person description (vv. 1-7) to second-person address (vv. 8-9) and back to third-person (vv. 10-12) function rhetorically and theologically?
What is the agricultural metaphor's significance in 'Light is sown for the righteous' (v. 11), and how does this 'sowing' imagery relate to divine providence and eschatological hope?
How does Psalm 97 relate to other 'YHWH malak' psalms (93, 96, 97, 98, 99) in terms of shared themes, vocabulary, and theological development?
What is the relationship between 'judgments' (מִשְׁפָּטֶיךָ) in v. 8 and the earlier 'justice' (מִשְׁפָּט) in v. 2, and how do these terms function in the psalm's moral theology?
micro_questions: Why does the psalm specify 'many islands' (אִיִּים רַבִּים) rather than 'all nations' - does this reflect maritime trade routes or eschatological geography?
How does the theological paradox in v.2 function - can divine hiddenness (clouds/darkness) and moral clarity (righteousness/justice foundation) coexist?
What is the identity and significance of 'all divine beings' (כׇּל־אֱלֹהִים) in v.7 - angels, foreign deities, or divine council members?
Why does light get 'sown' (זָרֻעַ) in v.11 - is this agricultural metaphor about delayed harvest, hidden growth, or providential planting?
How does the double מִלִּפְנֵי (at the presence of) in v.5 function poetically and theologically - mere emphasis or escalating revelation?
Why do the heavens 'proclaim' righteousness while peoples only 'see' glory (v.6) - different types of divine revelation?
What triggers the shift from cosmic scope (vv.1-6) to particular focus on Zion/Judah (v.8) - is this liturgical, theological, or poetic necessity?
